description.raw:
As idenitifed in #373, there's a need for standalone versions of important models like the Atlas.  Users should be able to load such models into their own software without ROS, or even Gazebo.  They just need to be able to parse SDF/URDF.

In drcsim 3.1.0, we moved to a runtime-spawn model, with xacro generation, that has made it much more difficult to load these models.

This pull request adds some steps to the build to generate, for each `foo.urdf.xacro` file, a `foo` model.  These models go into a `standalone_models` directory, one for each package.

To test this:

* Install Gazebo (e.g., 2.0.0)
* Build and install drcsim from this branch.
* In a fresh shell, without any ROS or drcsim setup files, add some directories to your `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` and run Gazebo:

        export GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH=<install_prefix>/share/atlas_description/standalone_models:<install_prefix>/share/irobot_hand_description/standalone_models:<install_prefix>/share/multisense_sl_description/standalone_models
        gazebo

    You can now insert any of the various flavors of Atlas, the iRobot hand, or the Multisense head.  There are no plugins loaded (those need ROS), to the models will be uncontrolled.

Usage will vary from case to case, but I would imagine that folks like @jespersmith will copy the content of the `standalone_models` directories somewhere else, to be read by their own software.
